text.p: These are the leading stories in the Namibian press on Wednesday.
Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- After nearly 30 hours of protest against their prolonged unemployment, demonstrating former liberation fighters were last night relocated from parliament gardens to the showgrounds.

- The National Society for Human Rights in its 1996 report claims that Namibia's current style of government is characterised by authoritarianism, elitism and political intolerance. It says neither the ruling SWAPO party nor the South African forces have revealed what happened to about 2,000 Namibians missing during the liberation struggle.
- Prime Minister Hage Geingob told parliament that the national intelligence service needs more powers.
- The National Society for Human Rights has accused the Namibian defence and police forces of killing more than 370 people over two years, and burying them in mass graves on the Kavango river.
- Tougher measures against rapists will be discussed in the National Assembly on Wednesday.

- Namibian employees can look forward to receiving similar pay increases to last year, according the latest Namibian Remuneration Survey published by Johannesburg-based human resource consultants FSA-Contact.
